name: Braid
description: Braid is a puzzle-platformer, drawn in a painterly style, where you can manipulate the flow of time in strange and unusual ways. From a house in the city, journey to a series of worlds and solve puzzles to rescue an abducted princess.
minimum_requirements: Operating System: Microsoft® Windows® XP / Vista / 7                   Processor: 1.4GHz or faster                     Memory: 768 MB or more                     Hard Disk Space: 200 MB or more                     Video Card: Pixel Shader 2.0                     DirectX® Version: DirectX® 9.0c                     Controller Support: Microsoft Xbox 360 Controller for Windows

reviews.review_text: Fantastic, intelligent, brilliant and with a lot of spirit, this has to be, beside Fez, one of the best platformers I have ever played. Highly recommended if you wannt use your brain. :)  Art style is also beautiful, music pleasant.       Graphics:    ★★★★☆     Sound:    ★★★★☆     Gameplay:    ★★★★★     Music:    ★★★★★                  Overall:     ★★★★★
One word for each aspect of this game.
A brilliantly designed game featuring smart puzzles, excellent music, beautiful art and a meaningful narrative executed perfectly within the mechanics of the game.

This game belongs with Portal and Antichamber on any list of the best puzzle games ever made. All the puzzles involve time manipulation in some way and they are all original ideas you won't have seen before. The last level is one of the most clever I've ever seen and the plot is deep and thought-provoking. It's very hard to find anything to complain about here.

My wife and son left town for a week to visit relatives. I took off work to take care of and spend precious time with my 1 and 2 year old daughters. When they were awake, we strolled around the block, went for car rides, played toys, When they were alseep...one word...Braid. Special week. This game messes with your mind in such a good way. It's a difficult physical puzzle game played as a platformer. The story is deeper, albeit slightly hard to follow, than I expected. I had never rewinded time in a video game before Braid. The concept is borderline genius, and Jonathan Blow (creator) runs with it with surprising results. I'll recommend this game to gamers who don't get frustrated easily, who like the satisfaction after a difficult puzzle is solved, and who don't mind thinking before acting in a platformer. If it gets too difficult, there's always the Internet:)
Its like Maplestory...but with time travel...and hints of ♥♥♥♥!!!!

This may be the greatest puzzle platformer ever made. What's so great about it? Firstly, the timetravel-based mechanics make for unconventional and diffult puzzles. Learning to think about yourself in time loops is extremely challenging and rewarding. With each world (or level), the game introduces a new timetravel mechanic that adds another layer of complexity to the puzzles. The puzzles become so hard that at certain points I had headaches and had to stop playing. But that pain is worth the payoff of finally being able to figure out a puzzle after spending an hour steaming at the ears. You feel like a God, until you reach the next puzzle.   But the best payoff of all is the twist at the end of the story. The story is primarily told through books read at the beginning of each world. The writing in this game is extremely contemplative and existential, dealing with topics like memories, identity, and the nature of relationships. The writing beautifully weaves into the timetravel mechanics for each world. The design of the mechanics, their ability to be relevant to the story, and their ability to make the game's puzzles more complex at the same time, is the product of genius. The story, like a poem, doesn't explain itself. It leaves itself open to interpretation. The replayability of this game is in the different meanings that can be thought of upon further playthroughs of the game.  The music of the game fits the aestitic of the art style and reflects the mood of the story very well. The gravity of the twist near the end of the story is helped by the music. The music plays a role in telling the game's story.  In conclusion, this game is the greatest puzzle platformer because it ties the story, gameplay mechanics, and music together SO WELL that I would go back in time to experience the game all over again for the first time (small Braid joke). If you like puzzle platformers and you don't buy this game, WHAT ARE YOU EVEN DOING?

Braid was the first 'big indie' game that I played. Braid was also the first game for me to really do a double-take on the Indie genre. Played as a 2D side scroller with a Mario-esque set-up (save the princess), it turns convention and expection on its head more than once - cleverness.   Many of the puzzles are difficult, but in most cases so cleverly designed that when figured out, you realize how simple they are - cleverness.   Braid is a tremendous argument for the awesomeness that the Indie genre can be. A must play for anyone interested in puzzle-platformers.
This game is pretty fun but I can't imagine spending too much time with it. Great for people who like puzzles and platforming.

This isn't a bad game, it suffers from being overly hyped. Braid is very nice to look at, but I wouldn't say that everything is very well executed. The fact that certain mechanics are never given a decent explanation (i.e. what the arbitrary limitations are) makes a lot of this game very frustrating personally. I do like puzzles and games based around them, but there are too many times to me where the solutions have seemed 'fiddly', for lack of a better word. You may understand the solution perfectly well, but it may be unnecessarily difficult, often due to the awkward platforming elements. All in all I have some enjoyable moments in the game, but I am very glad I got it on sale because this is simply not worth $10. The visuals are extremely polished, the gameplay could have used more work in my opinion. The underlying story is also boring me to tears.

This game is truly unique and beautiful. The soundtrack and art is inspiring to behold. Besides all that great stuff the game is very fun as well. The game play involves controlling time forwards and backwards as well as copying yourself in forwards or backward to complete objectives to move forward. Overall an excellent play. 10/10

Puzzle platformers tend to be platform games with a few easy puzzles. Braid is a puzzle games with some easy platform elements. The puzzle mechanic is one of the most innovative I have seen. It involves time manipulation and challenges you to think in new ways to predict the consequences of manipulating time in various ways and use this ability to achieve your goals. It starts out easy and the difficulty ramps up at a good pace. Towards the end the game is challenging even for experienced puzzle solvers. The game is also non-linear in that you don't need to solve everything in one part of the game to progress to later parts, if you get stuck on a puzzle you can go somewhere else and come back to tackle that puzzle later. The game has an artistic style that feels completely natural and fits well with the unique style of the gameplay. Graphics and sound contribute further to make the game atmospheric. The story is told in various ways, including texts you can read at the start of each level but also, in a way, through the pictures that you need to assemble to complete a level. All in all this is one of the best puzzle platformers I have played and highly recommended to anyone who likes puzzle games.

Braid's become kinda legendary since it's release. It's usually touted as one of the few games that manages to be 'art' or at least it's managed to be considered art outside of the gaming community, which is apparently what people are really shooting for.  But on its own merits, Braid is really a brilliant game.  It's a puzzle-platformer where everything is built around time manipulation mechanics including going back in time, stopping time, speeding up time, etc.  The story and gameplay though is a deconstruction (there's that art game thing coming in) of traditional video game tropes, specifically the old Mario games.  The art and music are beautiful, and there's a lot of subtle hidden themes revealed through writing samples you gain throughout the game.  There's far more secrets as well, some are insanely difficult to find. Just search special ending for braid in youtube and you'll be astounded.  Overall it's definitely recomended. It's fun to play and explore, although some sections are very difficult.
Great game, great puzzles, great meanings.

This is one of those artsy indie games. Also one of the first larger successes in the 'public' indie scene. The game itself it a platform puzzle game with elements or references from games like Mario and homages to several other 'old school' NES games. There also is a very interesting mechanic that is important to the core of the gameplay; Rewinding time. This little feature will prove more important than a simple 'save point'-feature in games such as Prince of Persia: SoT. In Braid certain elements are unchained from the time/space continuum - In other words, you can rewind time and unchained elements will stay put, or if you are holding them; Follow you back to where you were.  This entire process is used cleverly in the puzzles you are faced with.  Apart from the puzzles there is a very neat story tucked into the game(as with most artsy indie titles). Without getting into too much detail on that part; It reminds me of a very well known 'Save the captured Princess' scenario... With a twist. I'm not going to spoil it and I'll leave it up to you to figure out the rest.  It's a short but great game - clocking at around 5-6 hours to beat it. For what it is, it's well worth the time spent.
To play this game your brain wlil require some thinking . Creating a game like Braid requires you to be a genius .

Braid took 6hrs to complete everything, so while this is a short game, it is quite satisfying. The time manipulation puzzles are very rewarding throughout, and are complimented by a nicely written soundtrack and story.

So what do you get when you combine something only understood by those who analyze Shakespear for hours and time travel? Something like Braid.  Braid's best feature is the awesome power of going back in time if you mess something up. What isn't mentioned is what this entitles as well. Going back in time at twice the speed allows you to beat objects unneffected by time travel to their destination, small gold rings create black holes in which time travels at a near stop, and creating copies of yourself by doing something you would do normally and then traveling back in time to do something else. Each world has its own unique time power (even the last) that the game gives only subtle hints about and I went bonkers (in a good way) having to figure that out for myself. That said, the game's short and will probably be finished within three hours if you're looking for all the puzzle pieces. GOOD LUCK WITH THAT. A beautiful game to witness and hear, yet still fun to play.
This game aged well. Still blows my mind with how amazingly good it is.
Awesome time feature, difficult riddles plus beautiful soundtrack and interesting plot - 'must-buy' game for every gamer.
A beautiful and haunting story, told in a mind-bogglingly unique way.
Amazing game. Addictive, but some of the levels are very challenging. Worth it if you like any sort of puzzle game.
This is one of the most beautiful gaming experiences you will ever have.
The greatest mind♥♥♥♥ you have ever experienced.

Worth playing almost entirely because of how unique it is. The mechanics are clever, the visuals are pretty, and it doesn't take too long. I wasn't a huge fan of the story, mostly because I couldn't make out what the hell was going on, so it mainly came off as a bunch of pretentious '2deep4u' crap. Still fun.

This platformer wears its Super Mario influences on its sleeve but adds the twist of time manipulation. The art direction is great and some of the levels are very challenging. Braid is the embodiment of the Indie Darling.
This game is a very challenging and beautiful game. This game can get very difficult and unfair at time. I give this game a 8/10

This game is ingenious.   Seriously, my mind felt like it was being thoroughly stretched and distorted by the twisted challenges offered by Braid.   Buy this game. Buy it twice and grind the second copy up, turn it into pill form and be like Bradley Cooper in the movie Limitless.*     *Don't do drugs.
One of the best indie games of all time. I wish all games were braid.

You ready for mind♥♥♥♥? You better be, because this game will steal your brain's virginity like there's no tomorrow, then it'll take a break and have a cigar before it flips you over and comes back for seconds. It requires some thinking to master, so you gotta be smart to play this!

Over rated and convoluted. Much of this game's praise seems to stem from is setting and story rather than mechanics, but I found it to be the other way around. Keeping it short... The time-reversal based puzzles were impeccably creative. They were fun, mostly fair challenges to navigate. The story's attempt to be deep ends up being head-scratchingly vague with many nonsequential nuggets of it delivered throughout. Having time manipulation as your game's theme isn't much of an excuse for just mashing a myriad of vagueries together and expecting people to find it deep and brooding (which apparently lots did.) Even after looking up a detailed story/ending synopsis, the ultimate 'true ending' is hardly tantamount to the work it requires to puzzle it out.  I bought this game expecting a short and sweet but heavily impactful emotional trip like the amazing 'Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons', but was left with just a quaint, fun little indie platformer.  Would reccomend if on sale for a buck or three. Excellent soundtrack.
A masterpiece of a puzzle game! A really ingenious piece of work! I loved every second of it! Find all stars if you can!
Interesting, challenging and fun.

A wonderful and challenging Puzzle solving game. The Story was superb and everything about this game makes it great till the end. I do advise you to read up about the star pieces before you play this if you think you want to get them (they are not required), otherwise you won't be able to get one of the stars later on if you want to get them.

A wonderful experience. Deciphering and mastering the different uses of time in this game is a delight. Somewhat 'pretentious', but the sense of accomplishment as you solve each level can't be denied. A really refreshing change of pace.
Great FPS, would recomend to anyone who is a fan of the 'Badrats' franchise.
fun and novel gameplay, recommended to everyone to try at least once.
Solid unique platformer with an interesting story

At this point it really isn’t news that if you like indie puzzle games you should play Braid. This game is part of the canon—and for very good reason. Braid is a beautiful piece of craftsmanship.  The core engine of Braid is a simple, 2D platformer reminiscent of Mario. (The resemblance to classic Mario is more than passing, and the creators of Braid overtly nod to it at several points.) But to the simple mechanics of jumping and dodging Braid has added a novel element: the ability to reverse time. At the touch of a button you can rewind your performance of a stage to whatever point you like and then begin again from that point.  That alone would be novel, but not worth much—just an alternative to replaying levels—but Braid makes this mechanic the central tool in the solution of an array of tricky puzzles. At first your control of time is just a way of undoing mistakes, but it quickly takes on other dimensions as you, for example, discover items which are immune to your powers and so keep moving normally while all else rewinds. Solutions to the problems Braid poses are not usually a matter of muddling through, trying things until something works, but instead involve having some insight about the central mechanic and how it affects your surroundings. Like a good riddle there is a moment of dawning insight and suddenly you see things in a new way.  And the surroundings are themselves wonderful. While the mechanics of the game would be worthy regardless (an early version of Braid won a game design award while the graphics were still just place holders) the graphics makes the game into a piece of visual art. Everything in Braid looks hand-made in the best possible sense. The levels have an almost water colored look. And while there are actually fairly few sprites in the game, corresponding to the small number of pieces out of which levels are constructed, the background elements are various and gorgeous. Each group of puzzles has a distinct aesthetic subtly adapted to the content of the gameplay. Beautiful, low key instrumental music compliments all this perfectly. This game is simply pretty, and in a way that makes playing it feel meditative.  The story, provided mostly by textual interludes, is rather impressionistic. I found it difficult to make sense of, and in the end not entirely satisfying. But nonetheless thematic elements intertwine with the gameplay. The most obvious example is that you play as a man troubled by regrets, and this theme of regret resonates in the mechanic of undoing actions you have already performed.  Braid is a piece of art, pure and simple, but as already mentioned it is also a tightly designed puzzle game. This means some stages are rather challenging, as they should be. However, a nice feature is that the puzzles are not locked into strict sequence. If the needed insight simply will not come in one place then it is open to the player to skip ahead and return for the missing bits much later, lessening the potential frustration that’s part of puzzle games.  Braid has taken simple parts, things that have been around since 8-bit consoles, and polished them until they shone. Play it. You’ll be glad you did.

Braid is an intriguing game where you use the power to rewind time to solve a variety of platform puzzles. As you progress through the game, you encounter new and different effects that give each level a unique challenge. Although there is some written plot, the game is driven mostly by player action.  The biggest turnoff I've found for this game is that it was very poorly ported from console. You *can* use a keyboard, but its very uncomfortable and goes against keyboard control standards. And you can't change them. On top of that, you can't change any video settings, not even to go from fullscreen to windowed mode or the resolution. For my multi-monitor setup, that is annoying and distracting.  Overall, I say this game is very much worth playing. However, I strongly advise playing it in its native console form.

Definetly the HARDEST game i've ever play !!  'Come On. This will not be as hard as you said.'  Maybe yes. Braid introduces itself with simple puzzles that even 5 yo girl can finish those. But, in a mid-game you will experience new conditions that surely cause you to fail at first and want to give up already. These damn 'barriers' sometimes so annoying and you will struggle with them until the end of game.  There are many walkthrough videos which uploaded by those smart guys on community hub and you can just follow those instruction to get all the puzzle pieces quite easily. But, will you still getting scared by a horror movie when you're already know when those ghosts will appear? Same goes with BRAID, the real experience come if you try to solve the puzzles by yourself.  Other than that, Braid gives some heavenly soothing atmosphere through good music and nice graphic. These things are what i think the best part of this game. There also will be many references of many old popular games you have played before.  In my conclusion, this game is not for everyone (as others told it too) but for you who likes puzzles and willing to strrugle with them will find yourself immersed in the game and somehow addicted to it. Giving it 8/10 (because it's hard).

Everybody makes mistakes. After all to err is human, but what if we revisit our past, fix the problems we create and come out the better for them? This is the crux of Braid, a game that at it's core, is about someone who has done something very bad and is now doing everything in their power to wind back the clock and make amends. Eloquently penned and highly symbolic it tells a story with a deliberate purpose, the details of which have been picked and scrutinized over. It's meant to be open ended, to inspire discussion, and ultimately to make you sit and ponder the outcome, which speaking purely from my own perspective caught me entirely off guard and was cause enough for me to pause and step away from it to contemplate what it all meant.  Built around the narrative (or perhaps the other way around) are the puzzles which again deal with the manipulation of time. At first it's simply a way out of the inevitable mishaps you get into, but as you progress they evolve into much more elaborate and inventive conundrums, continually changing up the rules while keeping the framework intact. Again and again I was astounded by the simple elegant way everything fit together, much like the jigsaw pieces you collect, each part feeling necessary and fleshed out. This goes a long way in keeping the puzzles challenging and absorbing, and although it is a short experience developer Jonathan Blow makes smart use of his time and doesn't waste yours with filler or sections that fall flat from poor execution.  The rich pastel backdrops that blend effortlessly with the stunningly animated sprites, create a scene that looks like a watercolor painting in motion. It's absolutely beautiful and perfectly matches the tone of the narrative, further complemented by the soundtrack which flows alongside it in time, seemingly telling its own story in the process. It's an artistic masterpiece that captivated and enchanted me the moment I laid eyes upon it, and the organic pacing kept me wholly engrossed throughout.  If you only play one puzzle-platformer in your time, Braid would be very close to the top of my list. It personifies the genre better than almost anything that came before it or after, and did so before the genre was anywhere near as prolific as it is today. If for some reason the story doesn't grab you the brilliant puzzle designs will, and those that look deeper be duly rewarded with what has been placed beneath the surface. I savored my time with it and am now, like our protagonist, wishing I could go back and relive it over again.

I barely wish for a game to have thumb that is neither up or down but just kinda 'meh'. Right there in the middle. On the other side I do not like it to have a 'meh' opinion. DAMN YOU BRAID! :D  Now, I know this game has been praised all up and down for being amazing, and it is. Except for the times when it is not.  To me, the most interesting parts about Braid are the art style and the core gameplay mechanic. While I can't do anything but praise the style of the game as well I will do so. Be praised Art Style! Your rock! The core mechanic, however, is a double edged sword. It basically is all about turning back and replaying time. You can do so manually at all times or sometimes you'll have a special time mechanic on your hands:  In example, when your movement is queued to the entire game world. Walking forward will move you and the time, standing still will freeze it and walking backwards will rewind it.  There are quite a few different time mechanics within Braid, but since I'm not all that evil I won't do spoilers here. Oh yeah you can walk and jump here. That's like the platforming part. It's solid but nothing special without the time travel thingy.  While this makes for an amazingly fresh gameplay experience, some of the puzzles tied to it are ridiculous. You'll spend hours upon hours to solve a single game screen just to get frustrated as hell, turning to a youtube guide if your computer can still play videos after you've tossed it through your entire apartement, out the window and ran it over with a truck. Twice.  Some of the puzzles later on even require the usage of tricks never hinted at, let alone explained wich just seems cheep. There may be the 1% of players who will dedicate their live to solving those puzzles without a guide but there's a 1% of people who try to invent time travel itself in the real world as well without much success. So yeah.   Another interesting thing are the collectables. You can run through almost the entire game, skipping all puzzles. Now it won't do you and good and you'll be done with the Braid within 15 minutes. So don't do it. Embrace the rage! By collecting certain things you'll uncover other certain things wich will uncover 6 very certain things and the games ending. Wich in itself is a thing. So ya. Getting those collectables is the goal of the game.  There are a few more things I wanna praise here to look in the mirror tomorrow morning, hating myself for being mainstream or something.  Yet another great apsect this game does have for it is the music. it's great. I do have the feeling that it is intendet to calm you while the hate about not solving puzzles inside you does grow to an infinite amount of pure rage. Just like the visual part of the game it feels 'real'. As in, all hand made. A warm piano accompanied by a soothing Cello charm your ears while you are afraid of blowing up the house on the other side of the street if your speakers fail to work all of a sudden. Or if you use the time mechanic (wich you have to) for it will rewind the soundtrack as well wich sounds god awful. So basically, the music makes you afraid of solving the game... Soundtrack, you've nailed it! Except for the fact that you make me staring at the screen not doing much at all cause I am afraid of rewinding you.  The story is surprisingly deep for a puzzle platformer. Not deep in the sense of an epic story that will unfold before you but deep as in you'll find yourself thinking about it... in fact, Braid is kinda vague on the story thing with a bunch of diaries as your only lore. But those diaries are, in fact, very well written and thought worthy... You'll (or can... there are those people) squeeze your thoughts in a philosophical attempt, triggered by those diaries in the game... with about 30% of your brain cells while the other 70% will be occupied crafting a pipe bomb you'll stick into your computer, watching it blow up in satisfaction about the running gamescreen fading to black while you'll get caught into the explosion. Story, you are awesome! Kind of.... Kant would like it I suppose.... or Tolstoi. Maybe...  (Dat ending though.... 12/10)  There are more likable aspects about this game (like dropping huge objects on people and jumping on heads) wich do result in the same awesome but not awesome part of the game. In the end, it is indeed a great game wich you should buy but it also sucks ♥♥♥ for it will ruin your day whenever you start it. Wich probably means you shouldn't buy it. So buy it! Or not! I dunno.   You'll have to answer yourself a simple question: Is the massive frustration worth the whole lot of joy you'll get from this game? I do not regret buying it at all but damn! This new computer was expensive!  Yet again... dat ending though! 13/10!   (if there are any typos I DON'T CARE CAUSE I'M RAGING!)    Oh did I meantion the ♥♥♥♥ing impossible to beat speed mode? I didn't? Shame on me!
Beautiful artwork, beautiful soundtrack, devious puzzles, and one of the greatest uses of mechanics as metaphor in the game's final moments.
One of the best story driven platformers around. The variations on time in the puzzles are delightful. Absolutely recommend. 11/10.
This is a game that utilizes a concept that's been used before, but takes it to its utmost reaches to deliver the thought of time in a fresh, challenging and engaging way. Kudos.
Awesome indie game! Beautiful music, great puzzles, gorgeous graphics. 10/10
One of the earliest indie games to make a name for itself and still one of the best.
A charming experience which never out-stays it's welcome and always manages to make you feel clever.
'If I could save time in a bottle, The first thing that I'd like to do, Is to save every day till eternity passes away, Just to spend them with you' -Jim Croce
Probably the most brilliant allegory in gaming history thus far. If you don't complete this game with all stars   and 'get it'  , go back to farmville. Filthy casual.

Braid is a curious game for a lot of reasons, despite it's impressive art style and legacy it actually isn't as enjoyable as it appears.   As the trailer suggests you are capable of turning back time, thus you never officially die. Despite this the leaning curve is quite steep and not always fair.  If anyone has heard of the Infamous Goat puzzle in Broken Sword this may make a bit more sense. But basically in the point and click adventure game Broken Sword there is a puzzle that requires quick timing. But you the player have never used it before, so what makes it so difficult is your lack of understanding and knowledge of a gaming mechanic. You are unaware that you are even capable of doing what the game expects you to do.  This is how Braid often feels. Although it is a very clever game many of puzzles require you to use your powers in unconventional ways to meet your goal. Although I never cared for tutorials or hand holding, the way it expects you to use your new abilities can often seem ridiculous and are incredibly specific.  As an example there's a part in the game that requires you to let an enemy kill you, by doing this you see that when the enemy kills you it jumps back upward as it falls on top of you. Similarly to how Mario would when killing a goomba.   But lets say you rewind too fast to realize this is something that can happen or you've never had an enemy kill you from above.  Because there's not really an oppuninity in the game dedicated to this very specific mechanic you might not know you're able to do this.   Since you don't know all the mechanics the game can feel as if it's cheating you. It's not that you didn't understand the puzzle but rather you didn't understand a mechanic that was never revealed properly in the first place.  Braid does this multiple times, which is where I find the most difficulty in the game.   As for the story? It's interesting but for lack of better words leaves you feeling empty of confused. Even when you do research into theories or see the ending of the game you just never feel as if you knew the whole experience. And that's not always bad but a lot of games can hold a sense of mystery while satisfying the player. This game just didn't satisfy me with it's conclusion.   Furthermore to complete the game in it's entirety you are required to collect stars. Many of which you as the player would never have even known were in the game. The first star in world 2 takes about an hour and a half to collect by standing on top of a cloud.  Let that sink in, how is the player expected to wait that long at the beginning of the game?   Perhaps later in the game a challenge like that is realistic after the player is aware that there are actual collectables. But for the completing the game it felt unfair. There is a star map at the intro but I was unaware that I could actually collect items for it as well.  Furthermore despite how interesting the story is the creator Johnathan Brow is rather pretentious in his attitude towards those theorizing or reviewing his game.  If you'd like to play it I'd suggest to avoid reading his lengthy interviews as they just leave a sour taste in your mouth and ruin the experience of a decent game.  It's normal for an artist to be protective of his work and to have a specific outlook or belief. Brow often justifies parts of critiques and mistakes as being intentional or experimental. Yet as an artist regardless of if an element is intentional or not that does not make the game improve in quality if it wont translate to the player. A game element needs to make sense not just in the eyes of the creator but the audience.    Furthermore the soundtrack is pretty but incredibly repetitive and many levels don't suit the soundtrack. Plus, a world in the game requires you to listen to the majority of it in slow motion or backwards and trust me when I say it gets irritating quickly.  The enemies feel uncreative, but I'm sure they serve some purpose in terms of appearance besides being a reference to Mario. Although the sound effects for the rabbits and goomba looking enemies are annoying.  So please before purchasing this game for 15 dollars just know that although it isn't a bad game it is overhyped. It might be a enjoyable use of your time but I don't believe it's worth the 15 dollar price tag.

At first glance it may look like a hipster version of Mario { something it's not shy about hinting at itself } but at it's core Braid is more of a puzzle game with a platformer interface. It is at times very challenging and fighting the urge to do a search on youtube for the way to clear an area could be tough for many people.  Visually it has a timless art style which keeps it seperate from the graphic spec' fights of contempory titles and as a 2D game it is not overly taxing on the machine it is played on.   The Story, though hidden in a way, is actually quite deep & somber but i'll not spoil it. The length of the game is on the short side but for most people the puzzels will slow them down enough to get a good few gaming sessions out of it. Gameplay wise, it is inventive and surprisingly intuitive. There is little need for any tutorial beyond trying out the variations on the mechanics each world brings.   The real downside is probably the replayabillity once you have collected all of the puzzle-pieces. Speed players may go back to try and beat their time but beyond that not much would bring the player back post completion.   While most games out there lately seem to be either clones of other games or made to be easy to beat, this is refreshingly challenging. It looks good and it plays well. If you like platformers and puzzels, get it.

I find the time travel mechanic pretty unique, but the game overuses it. I found that all the puzzles were challenging, for me anyway. One of my problems with this game is for those people who aren't really into it for the collecting can sometimes just simply walk right to the exit. I found this games puzzles interesting and creative, using the time travel really well. But some of these are nearly impossible and the fact that i could just walk right past it was really annoying. Take world 2. The ... hedgehogs, I guess, were getting fired out of the cannon and you had to time it perfectley to make it across the gap. I ended up just walking right past it after trying MANY times to make it. And the no dying? Breaks alot of gaming rules. Dying is part of how gaming works. And besides, it's not like it helps you. It takes you back to exactly where you are and for most of it all it helps you with is knowing that you were off by a few seconds. Pretty useless. The game fails to tell you anything about what things do and how they work. I had to figure out how to go back in time which i caught on to at the start of the second world. The story was pretty dull and boring so i really didn't pay attention to the text. The game isn't exciting. The music is bland, the puzzles can be repetitive, the story is boring, the game is confusing, and it's just not that fun.They even started reusing puzzles! I swear, the first world has a parkour to the end level. 2 worlds later, they have the exact same level, but you have to kill all the monsters on your way. Again, the game overuses the time travel. Need to revive, time travel. Kill a boss, time travel. Timed something wrong, time travel. Do anything wrong whatsoever, you guessed it. TIME TRAVEL! To sum it up, this game is probably the worst I currently have on Steam. It's just different for me cause i'm used to sidescrollers to having killing things, platforming, and making to the end of the stage. Not going back in time to solve problems, having optional puzzles on the way, and taking a nice lovely stroll through a bland field and occasionally jumping over a hedgehog. This game gets a 2 out of 5.

One of the best games I've played in the last decade, Braid is a puzzle platformer about time and motion. Our little hero cannot die, because he can control time forward or backwards, including its speed. This might look like a simple concept, but wait until you see what the devs have made of this. The puzzles are mind-blowing. In each new world, you will have some different powers than on the others. Your main power (the time rewind) will still work as usual, but now it can have some side effects.   For example, in world 4, time forwards when you walk to the right and rewinds when you walk to the left. In world 5, after rewinding, a shadow of yourself does the same thing you did before rewinding.   The graphics and ambient are gorgeous, control is good, time manipulating powers are fun to use, and puzzles are hard enough (but with good progression) to be satisfying to solve.
It's an amazing game with a deeper meaning, if you want to search for it.

This is easily one of the most creative and original games that I've ever played. I loved the soundtrack. Jonathan Blow's decision to license the music--music written by composers for the sake of the art, not because they needed another track for a level--was excellent. The writing and story were superb! I can't say strongly enough how much I enjoyed the story (though to get the full story, you have to get the stars and getting the stars without looking up how is near impossible). The game mechanics were fun, consistent, and well thought out. The puzzle design is by far the stand out feature here. Of course there's the 'respect for the player's time' and 'no filler' points that they make (and fulfill), but for me the excellence of the puzzle design is that each puzzle has a definite, 'low impedance' answer (or answers, could be more than one, but each of them definite as I'll explain). Each solution is singular within the mechanics of the game, without introducing artificial limitations that contradict the rest of the game. There's no randomly twiddling with stuff until you slip past. While some games have some puzzles with no clear reason why the solution works, in Braid, discovering 'why' the solution works comes first, and is the only real requirement to solving the puzzles. If you've never played Braid, I envy the experience you have waiting.
Defiently a masterpice. Check this out if you havn't already.

This game has a lot going for it-- a deep story, pretty graphics, some of the best music, and great gameplay.  The story is not at all forced. There are several books lined up at the start of each world, and you can just run right past them without even reading them if you like. However, if you go deeper, you discover just how thorough the story is. Check the internet if you can't figure it out, because I don't want to spoil it. It'll blow your mind.  The game allows you to rewind time, so even if you fall to your death, you can undo it. It allows you to mess up and know you messed up, but then it doesn't take away the last five minutes of your life by making you redo the level and re-obtain what you got. That's a daring move, but it works for a game like this.  Braid is an experience. There are few games that aren't just fun but also artistic and mind-blowing. Braid is the few.

My rating: 8 / 10  Braid is a thought-provoking, yet short adventure that will puzzle you to the very end.  Pros:  - Beautiful visuals. The game feels like a watercolor painting. - Pretty soundtrack that never feels stale. - Unique puzzles based on time manipulation that are a fun challenge. - Very intelligent, though purposefully ambiguous storyline. - Fun secret areas with some of the game's most difficult puzzles.  Cons: - Some puzzle elements lack explanation (which may be a plus for those who prefer it) and may add unnecessary confusion to a task. - One (optional) secret item in the game requires the player to wait nearly two hours for a simple task.  Braid is a challenging puzzler that requires out-of-the-box thinking and will keep you in a problem-solving state of mind from the title screen all the way to the inspiringly well thought out ending. This indie classic is something that all intelligent gamers should experience at least once.

I saw this game on Xbox Live about 7 or so years ago before posting this review. It looked interesting when I played it, and I remember always wanting to do a full playthrough. After a long time, I finally did.  This is a puzzle game, and it's a very unique one. Rather than simply going through a maze a certain way or doing things in a certain order, you reverse time and manipulate objects around you. Certain objects have certain characteristics, like some objects *only* move if you move as well, or some objects are unaffected by time reversal.  It's a pretty cool game with a pretty good storyline that's kind of a spin-off of Mario, with you chasing a princess to other castles/fortresses, etc. Maybe not worth $15 if puzzle games aren't your thing, but still worth a playthrough.  7/10

[10/10] Braid is a puzzle-platformer with a great story. The puzzles are unique, combining platforming with the ability to rewind, making puzzles difficult, but not unfair. The art style is some of the best I've ever seen in a video game. Its story is something that can only be eperienced through playing it for yourself.

Buy this game.   Better yet, buy the bundle that includes this game so you can get half the games i reccomend on here for like $7.   Also the soundtrack is really good

Games that involve time travel and alteratin of time usually have a lot of potential, but what 'Braid' is showing here is simply mindblowing. You can move time back and fourth anyway you please and in every world, the challenges are getting tougher and tougher as new elements of time sensitive puzzles are introduced, keeping the gameplay exciting from start to finish. The story is told as text at the beginning of each world and slowly unfold things in front of you. It seems simple at first but only at the end, the (shocking) truth is revealed and not only that, if you manage to find the biggest secrets in the game, you can find another ending that is subject to interpretation and shows a far sinister story, taken from our real history. Gameplay, graphics and story are all very good, give the game a try!

A game with a somewhat confusing storyline and interesting puzzles. The levels are really well made and the gameplay is varied, allowing the player to rewind your actions and manipulate time to achieve incredible and really fun results.  That said, it's a game to very pacient players who really like to think. Some puzzles are incredbly complicated, specially if you want to get all the collectables (it gives you a different ending). The stars are painful to get and you don't even know that there are stars to collect to begin with unless you're really, REALLY creative (or read a walkthrough, as I did). I don't have this pacience; I had to watch videos to be able to finish it. But if you're a puzzle fan, this game definitively deserves a shot.

Pretty incredible experience packed into a compact game. The focus, and the reward, is how the story itself is told simultaneously by reading through pages on-screen as well as discovering time-bending gameplay mechanics. You might think 'Oh I've played with rewind features in Prince of Persia', but Braid is at its best when you as the user step back and wonder what it really means to rewind time. Are all thing turned back perfectly, giving you a second chance, or maybe somethings are outside of your control. Perhaps a mere shadow of yourself survives, or are you the shadow of a now future self? Maybe you shouldn't have tried messing with time in the first place.  9/10

Where do I start? Much unlike the name implies there is a complete lack of braids. In fact there is only one braid in the entire game! If you're looking for real hair mechanics and braid physics this is not the game. Wish that developers wouldn't be misleading. 3 hairy knees out of 5

Easily one of the smartest and well-constructed games I've played, Braid is a puzzle game disguised as a platformer. And don't be fooled by the demo, as there's a lot more to the game than rewinding to avoid death. Like Portal, Braid takes just a few concepts (e.g. rewinding time, enemies immune to time manipulation) and hammers out puzzles that make the most out of only a few mechanics.   Do you suck at puzzles and get easily frustrated? No problem! Braid is designed so that you can skip over tough puzzles and come back to them later. And when you come back and solve a difficult puzzle, the feeling of accomplishment will be great.   And the rewind mechanic is guaranteed to lessen the frustration associated with platforming games. If you mistime your jump, you simply rewind the game and do it right the next time. Trust me, instead of making the game too easy, it makes the game more playable.   This game will make you feel smart. Play it!

Braid is an incredibly hyped game, and one of the few that I think really deserves it. This game was revolutionary in its time.  Braid is a basic puzzle/platformer with an interesting philosophy: instead of punishing players for making mistakes, reward them for the lessons they learn. You get a variety of time-based powers, the most basic of which is to reverse time, allowing you to undo any bad move. But, this concept is explored very creatively. In one world, time is reversed by moving left and moves forward when you move right. In another, you can slow time down, but only for certain parts of the screen.  Some of the puzzles are very hard. I remember using a walkthrough for one or two of them.  Braid's story is an interesting metaphor that is delivered very well. It starts with a Mario-esque story, but the metaphor's depth is revealed by the end. The art and music are lovely.  Absolutely worth it for $10.

The Good: - The puzzles in this game are remarkably innovative. It is clear that a tremendous amount of condensation was put into designing each puzzle so that nothing felt superfluous or too convoluted.  - The art design can simply be described as beautiful. Beyond the sheer elegance of the art style, the aesthetic managed to brilliantly communicate the emotional subtext of the written narrative.   - The music in Braid was absolutely superb.   The Bad: - (No spoilers) my biggest gripe with Braid was the way in which the final arch of the story was told. Instead of proving context to clarify and give unambiguous meaning to the events of Tim’s journey, the story’s conclusion was muddied by more abstraction. Additionally, if popular interpretations are correct, then the intended story could have been more effectively fleshed out from the onset.   Final Verdict: To me, I relished the journey of Braid, not only due to the art design and puzzles on screen but also in my attempts to decipher the story before its conclusion. Whereas I assumed the curtain would eventually be pulled back, I was disappointed by the unnecessary ambiguity in the final act. Nonetheless, the game is still worth playing, albeit at a discounted price.

Few words better describe Braid than difficult, thoughtful and rewarding.

Braid is a brilliant game that gives you a rich, satisfying experience. The surface mechanics of the game are very similar to the old Super Mario World, but the twist that makes it fundamentally different is the ability to manipulate the flow of time either forwards or backwards, which makes for some truly ingenious puzzles. In addition to being able to move backwards and forwards through time, each of the five main worlds of Braid introduces a new element to the spacetime manipulation that keeps the puzzles fresh and intriguing. While the storyline has a distinct stream-of-consciousness style and can be hard to follow, the artwork and the soundtrack make for an aesthetically pleasing ride through the game. All in all, one of the best and most memorable games I've yet played.

Having first played The Witness (the other game made by Braid's creator--Jonathan Blow), I really should have expected Braid to be exactly what is was. Yet, I was very surprised to see just how similar it is in feeling to The Witness. If you have not played either game, they are both puzzle games with a main concept for solving the puzzles that is built to be more complex as the levels progress. And here's the important thing to know about either game: They're VERY difficult. I wouldn't recommend Braid to everyone, but if you want a challenging puzzle game, then Braid is an excellent choice. It is well designed and polished, and, if you can bear the difficulty, then it is very rewarding to play.
